S3.T1.caption:
Table 1: Compute and memory for computing the
meta-gradient when using a δ𝛿\delta–accurate 𝒜​l​gi𝒜𝑙subscript𝑔𝑖\mathcal{A}lg_{i}, and the
corresponding approximation error. Our compute time is measured in
terms of the number of ∇ℒ^i∇subscript^ℒ𝑖\nabla\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{i} computations. All results
are in O~​(⋅)~𝑂⋅\tilde{O}(\cdot) notation, which hide additional log factors; the error bound hides additional problem dependent Lipshitz and smoothness parameters (see the respective Theorem statements).
κ≥1𝜅1\kappa\geq 1 is the condition number for inner objective Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} (see Equation LABEL:eq:update_rule), and D𝐷D is the diameter of the search
space.
The notions
of error are subtly different: we assume all methods solve the inner
optimization to error level of δ𝛿\delta (as per definition 1). For our algorithm, the error refers to the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error in the computation of 𝒅𝜽​ℒi​(𝒜​l​gi⋆​(𝜽))subscript𝒅𝜽subscriptℒ𝑖𝒜𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑔⋆𝑖𝜽\bm{d}_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{i}(\mathcal{A}lg^{\star}_{i}({\bm{\theta}})). For the other algorithms, the
error refers to the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error in the computation of 𝒅𝜽​ℒi​(𝒜​l​gi​(𝜽))subscript𝒅𝜽subscriptℒ𝑖𝒜𝑙subscript𝑔𝑖𝜽\bm{d}_{\bm{\theta}}\mathcal{L}_{i}(\mathcal{A}lg_{i}({\bm{\theta}})).
We use Prop 3.1 of Shaban et al. [53] to
provide the guarantee we use. See Appendix D for additional discussion.
references:
Table 1 summarizes our complexity results and compares with MAML and
truncated backpropagation [53] through the path of the inner optimizer. We
use κ𝜅\kappa to denote the condition number of the inner problem
induced by Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i} (see Equation LABEL:eq:update_rule), which can be
viewed as a measure of hardness of the inner optimization
problem. Mem​(∇ℒ^i)Mem∇subscript^ℒ𝑖\textrm{Mem}({\nabla\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{i}}) is the memory taken to compute
a single derivative ∇ℒ^i∇subscript^ℒ𝑖\nabla\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{i}. Under the assumption that
Hessian vector products are computed with the reverse mode of
autodifferentiation, we will have that both:
the compute time and memory used for computing a Hessian vector product
are with a (universal) constant factor of the compute time
and memory used for computing ∇ℒ^i∇subscript^ℒ𝑖\nabla\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{i} itself
(see Appendix C). This allows us to measure
the compute time in terms of the number of ∇ℒ^i∇subscript^ℒ𝑖\nabla\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{i}
computations. We refer readers to Appendix D for additional discussion about the algorithms and their trade-offs.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Omniglot results. MAML results are taken from the original work of Finn et al. [15], and first-order MAML and Reptile results are from Nichol et al. [43]. iMAML with gradient descent (GD) uses 16 and 25 steps for 5-way and 20-way tasks respectively. iMAML with Hessian-free uses 5 CG steps to compute the search direction and performs line-search to pick step size. Both versions of iMAML use λ=2.0𝜆2.0\lambda=2.0 for regularization, and 5 CG steps to compute the task meta-gradient.
